title: Equities the winners in 'ugly' asset contest, fundies say
text:
Simon Mawhinney from Allan Gray said it's getting harder to find cheap stocks. "But it’s relative to those companies' own histories and the equity market’s broader history."

Equities "may well be cheap" relative to other asset classes, he said.

At some stage, interest rates will arrest their decline. "Stock markets are very forward-looking and that is a sign of a trade that you don’t want to be on the wrong side of," the fund manager cautioned, echoing similar comments by Magellan's Hamish Douglass and Platinum's Andrew Clifford.

Ms Howitt and Mr Mawhinney want companies to take a longer-term view and say they are prepared to support changes to achieve that aim, including imposing tougher remuneration policies.

Under pressure

Mr Mawhinney suggested companies could compensate executives with shares that would need to be held for up to a decade after they depart. "It may be a bit draconian but it makes companies particularly long-term focused," he said.

Fidelity is pushing for minimum shareholding requirements of at least two years post-exit, Ms Howitt said.

The fund managers acknowledged that boards are under pressure from short-term focused investors.

"Sometimes they are activists. They buy a stake and come in and agitate for a break-up of the business or some kind of catalyst to unlock value. I feel like those are smash and grabs," Ms Howitt said.

In those situations, "boards need to hear from longer term investors".

"You find that management feel all their shareholders just want earnings upgrades for the next six months, and the next six months, and it’s important for us to go and say, 'no, we will back you if you invest to make your business more resilient for the future'," Ms Howitt said.
description: It's more challenging to find cheap companies as interest rates fall, but equities are still less expensive than other assets.
